awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Novel Nonlinear and Quantum Multimode Optical Fiber and Waveguide Devices
awd_abstract_narration:
Objective:

The objective of this program is to explore, uncover, and control the rich nonlinear and quantum dynamics of light propagation that arise because of the presence of multiple, nonlinearly-coupled modes in multimode optical waveguides. This research is transformative in that it establishes a rigorous theoretical and experimental framework of this uncharted territory to develop fundamental understanding and to investigate novel device application.
In particular, efficient generation of quantum-entangled photon pairs in nonlinear multimode optical fibers will be explored in detail.

Intellectual merit:

The intellectual merit is to develop a parallel theoretical and experimental platform that integrates fundamental research on nonlinear and quantum dynamics of multimode waveguides with novel device applications.
The proposed research is in response to the emerging needs of the photonics community for a rigorous and comprehensive treatment of the nonlinear and quantum aspects of light propagation in multimode optical waveguides, such as in the emerging field of multimode-multiplexed fiber-optic communications for ultra-high-data-rate transmission, and for better security in quantum cryptography using the modal-entanglement platform.

Broader impacts:

The broader impacts are to obtain the mastery of nonlinear and quantum phenomena in multimode waveguides, which is vital to the national security and technological competitiveness of the United States for the development of the next generation of optical communication devices; and to integrate cutting-edge research with education using initiatives that include curriculum development, expansion of the photonics teaching laboratory, and continuing with the annual summer workshop program for teachers of the Milwaukee Public Schools system.

por.por_cntn:
The objective of this program has been to explore, uncover, and control the rich nonlinear and quantum dynamics of light propagation that arise because of the presence of multiple, nonlinearly-coupled modes in multimode optical waveguides. This research is transformative in that it establishes a rigorous theoretical and experimental framework of this uncharted territory to develop fundamental understanding and to investigate novel device application. Mastery of nonlinear and quantum phenomena in multimode waveguides is vital to the national security and technological competitiveness of the United States for the development of the next generation of optical communication devices; and to integrate cutting-edge research with education using initiatives that include curriculum development, expansion of the photonics teaching laboratory, and providing summer workshops for school teachers.

 

The intellectual merit has been to develop a parallel theoretical and experimental platform that integrates fundamental research on nonlinear and quantum dynamics of multimode waveguides with novel device applications. Efficient generation and control of quantum-correlated photon pairs in nonlinear multimode optical fibers has been explored in great detail in this project. The research is in response to the emerging needs of the photonics community for a rigorous and comprehensive treatment of the nonlinear and quantum aspects of light propagation in multimode optical waveguides, such as in the emerging field of multimode-multiplexed fiber-optic communications for ultra-high-data-rate transmission, and for better security in quantum cryptography using the modal-entanglement platform.

 

The research has shown that graded-index multimode fibers can be used as ultra-broadband sources of photon pairs with controlled spectral correlations, for applications in quantum information technologies. In particular, it has been shown that graded-index multimode fibers can be used as a tunable source of uncorrelated (or correlated) photon pairs, as their spectral correlations are relatively independent of the pump central wavelength using the nonlinear four-wave mixing process. While tuning the pump frequency will change the frequencies of the signal and idler, the signal (idler) photon state purity remains unchanged. Therefore, graded-index multimode fibers can be used to make quantum-state-preserving tunable sources of photon pairs. It has been shown that by the right selection of the physical parameters of the system including the fiber length and/or the pump bandwidth, it is possible to simultaneously generate correlated and uncorrelated photon pairs in the same optical fiber. Another major outcome of this research is a novel method to determine the statistics of photon sources to distinguish Coherent versus Thermal versus Number states.

 

In the area of classical nonlinear optics in multimode fibers, the researchers has fully uncovered the reason behind the apparent non-conservation of linear momentum of light and previous report on the apparent non-conservation of angular momentum of light in multimode optical fibers. This work highlights the peculiarities one encounters in dealing with such fibers. This phenomenon can be used for fiber mode conversion in device applications and unlike the linear coupling-based devices, no tuning of the fiber length is required and the modal conversion can be very efficient.

 

Several students have been trained under this program in various aspects of classical and quantum nonlinear optics, and guided-wave optics. The program has established the research infrastructure for tackling cutting-edge research problems in quantum information technologies in coming years, and has improved the education infrastructure of the participating university because of the new course designs and also improvements in existing courses and curricula. The outcomes of the research have been broadly disseminated to the public.
